content.heading: Network Components
content.text: In this simulation, you'll work with three types of network nodes that form the backbone of internet communication.

content.heading: Sender (S)
content.text: The Sender (S) node represents the source of data packets. This is where network communication begins. In real networks, this could be your computer sending a request to a web server.

content.heading: Autonomous Systems (AS)
content.text: Autonomous Systems (AS) are intermediate network nodes that forward data packets toward their destination. Each AS (like AS1, AS2, etc.) represents an independent network operator managing their own routing policies.

content.heading: Receiver (R)
content.text: The Receiver (R) node is the destination where data packets need to arrive. This represents the target server or service that the sender wants to communicate with.

content.heading: Network Paths
content.text: A path is the route data takes from Sender to Receiver through various AS nodes. The goal is to find valid paths that successfully deliver packets despite network failures.

content.heading: What is Network Routing?
content.text: Routing is the process of determining the optimal path for data packets to travel from source to destination across interconnected networks.

content.heading: Multiple Path Options
content.text: Real networks provide redundancy by having multiple routes between any two points. This ensures communication continues even when parts of the network fail. Notice how this level offers two different paths from S to R.

content.heading: Routing Protocols
content.text: In actual networks, protocols like BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) automatically calculate the best routes by sharing routing information between autonomous systems.

content.heading: Path Selection Criteria
content.text: Routing algorithms consider factors like: shortest path, least congestion, lowest cost, and reliability when choosing routes.

content.heading: Dynamic Adaptation
content.text: Modern routing systems continuously monitor network conditions and can switch to alternative paths within milliseconds when failures occur.

content.heading: Network Failures Are Inevitable
content.text: Network failures occur constantly in real internet infrastructure due to hardware malfunctions, fiber cuts, power outages, or maintenance.

content.heading: Impact of Single Points of Failure
content.text: Notice how breaking AS1 and AS3 eliminates one entire routing path. Good network design avoids single points of failure through redundancy.

content.heading: Fault Tolerance
content.text: Fault tolerance means the network continues operating despite component failures. This level demonstrates how alternative paths maintain connectivity.

content.heading: Failure Detection and Recovery
content.text: Modern networks use protocols that detect failures within seconds and automatically reroute traffic through working paths without human intervention.

content.heading: Designing Resilient Networks
content.text: Network architects build redundancy at every level: multiple ISPs, diverse physical paths, backup systems, and automatic failover mechanisms.

content.heading: Scaling Network Complexity
content.text: As networks grow larger, they become more complex with numerous interconnected autonomous systems forming intricate topologies.

content.heading: Mesh Networks
content.text: This level demonstrates a mesh-like topology where multiple connections exist between nodes, providing numerous routing options and increased resilience.

content.heading: Load Distribution
content.text: Complex networks distribute traffic across multiple paths to prevent congestion and optimize performance. Different routes may be chosen based on current network conditions.

content.heading: Hierarchical Routing
content.text: Large networks often use hierarchical structures where regional networks connect to backbone providers, creating efficient routing hierarchies.

content.heading: Network Optimization Challenges
content.text: Managing complex networks requires balancing multiple factors: performance, cost, security, and reliability while maintaining fault tolerance.

content.heading: Real-World Network Complexity
content.text: This ultimate challenge simulates the complexity of real internet infrastructure with multiple simultaneous failures and numerous routing options.

content.heading: Cascading Failures
content.text: Network failures can cascade through interconnected systems. Breaking AS1, AS5, and AS7 creates complex failure scenarios that test advanced routing strategies.

content.heading: Redundancy Planning
content.text: Enterprise networks require extensive redundancy planning with multiple ISPs, diverse physical paths, and automatic failover systems to maintain connectivity.

content.heading: Traffic Engineering
content.text: Network operators use traffic engineering techniques to optimize path selection, balance loads, and ensure quality of service across complex topologies.

content.heading: Network Monitoring and Analytics
content.text: Modern networks employ sophisticated monitoring tools that track performance metrics, detect anomalies, and predict potential failures before they impact users.
